Draft of possible letter to Raymond Hurlbert
Dear Raymond:
I'm afraid that the NAEB wouldn't be able to underwrite
two or three hundred dollars worth of expenses for you to visit with
Ed Marrow's office in Tokyo. Let me review the history of this situ-
xmxm±mam at ion as I recall it.
I believe
When the matter of your visit to Tokyo first came up,/Harry
Skornia told youy. that perhaps the NAEB could underwite any add it ional
costs you might incur as a result of any side trips you might under¬
take on behalf of NAEB. He cited as examples a couple of trips that
Burton Paulu and Marjorie Lundin undertook in Europe. However, the
only expenses paid to them were as reimbursement for the actual costs
they incurred to go from either London or Stockholm (Burton was in
London anyway, and Marjorie vias in Stockholm) to whatever city jbx a
meeting of interest to the NAEB was being held in.
In other words, the NAEB did not undertake to pay any of their
basic expenses ajS connected with their own primary mission. Applying
this to your case, since you are going to be in Tokyo anyway, there
would be no way for us to justify paying part of your expenses. If you
were to make a side trip to some other nation, specifically at our re¬
quest, we would then be able to pay the expenses of that side trip.
However, this would not help you any with your basic financial problem
so far as your trip to Tokyo is concerned, since we could pay only
the extra expesnes occasioned by such a side trip.
I'm sorry that this misunderstanding has not been cleared up
earlier, but I thought that it had been in earlier correspondence, and
that you understood the limitations upon our budget.
Naturally, if any side trip does come up which we feel would be
of specific benefit, we might be able to underwittte the costs, but this
still would not apply to your basic trip to Tokyo, or any points en route.
Sincerely 9
